elements.text: [Part One]
Explosions, alarms.
Hull breach. All bridge personnel please proceed immediately to escape modules. Hull integrity now at thirty four percent.
Hurry, Mel! We don’t have much time!
Doctor, I don’t understand. What’s going on?
This ship is under fire, and I sincerely doubt if our anticipating survivors.
But I thought they were delivering medical supplies.
Yes, precisely.
Boom! Creak of metal under strain.
That did not feel right.
No, definitely not. Stay close, we’re almost there.
What about the captain and all the crew?
I’m afraid Captain Hazeel was one of the first casualties. Our attackers focussed their initial salvo on the control dome. They knew exactly what they were doing.
Oh, that poor man.
Woman, Mel. Hazeel was a female of the species.
Really? But I thought you said those yellow things were
Look, Mel, through here. You can just see the enemy ship. Yes, there it is. It looks vaguely familiar.
Boom!
A lousy time for sight-seeing.
Agreed. This way, er, I think. (breathless) Ah, here we are. Quickly, Mel. Into the escape pod.
Wait. What about you?
I'll find you once I’ve located the Tardis. It’s er, it’s not far from here. Now go, please!
But Doctor
We really don’t have time for this, Mel. You must go now. Trust me.
Yes, all right, I’m going.

Welcome aboard escape module delta five jay. Please be seated, and fasten your safety harness as illustrated. When you are ready, depress the flashing green button on the console in front of you to launch this module.
Good luck, Doctor. See you
Soon, Mel. Very soon. Yes, once I’ve located the Tardis. I wonder where it is?
Please prepare for launch.
And how exactly do I prepare? I’m somehow reminded of my first time on the Big Dipper.
Escape module now disengaging. Hold tight please.
Here we go.
Reactor melt-down imminent.
Please, help.
Hello? Is someone there?
Please.
Keep talking. I can’t see you through all the smoke. I think I’m almost to you now.
Please.
Close explosion.
Hello? Hello? Oh. Oh dear. I’m sorry. (explosion, running) Ah! Ah, the Tardis at last. Truly a sight for irritated oculi. Time we were leaving.
Module now clearing blast radius.
Blast radius?
KaBOOM!
Oh no!
Module guidance systems are no longer receiving [??] Adjusting course. Emergency landing imminent.
Now what?
Crash-down in ten, nine
Crash-down?
Eight
Any chance of landing as opposed to crashing?
Five, four
Doctor!
Two
Rapid beeping stops. Tinkling music starts.
Good morning, Miss Bush.
Mel groans.
It is now five o’clock Lethean standard.
And I wanted to be awakened at this time because?
This morning you are required in the main laboratory.
Oh, that’s right. Lights to level five, please. Oh, best make that level two. And let’s lose the soundtrack. Oh, ah, oh. Well, I’m not going anywhere until I take a nice hot shower.
Current temperature of available water supply is twenty three point three three five degrees Celsius.
Almost tropical.
You have twenty six litres of water ration remaining.
I’ll just have to be quick. (showering) I don’t suppose there’s any sign of the Doctor?
Since your initial monitoring request seventy two days ago, no temporal disturbances of any kind have been detected by colony sensors.
Brr. It’s freezing. And the homing beacon?
Functioning normally.
Thank you. Oh, that’s so cold.
The Doctor groans.

Evelyn? Oh no. No, of course not. Mel. Mel? Where am I? Better still, when am I? Hello? Is anyone there? Focus, Doctor. You're in a large chamber. Hello? I'd say roughly thirty metres across by the sound of it. The unmistakeable though distant hum of interstellar engines. Spaceship. (sniffs) Oxygen with traces of argon and methane? Climate control almost non-existent. It’s freezing in here. And of course I appear to be restrained. Oh Mel, I’m afraid our rendezvous may be slightly delayed.
Mining shift A please report for duty in shaft fourteen.
Mel, wait up.
Oh, good morning, Geoff.
I got you some coffee.
Thanks. This morning I won't say no to the caffeine.
It’s decaffeinated. You know how the alkaloids interact with our security COMPUTERs.
You know, I am still not totally comfortable with this thing transmitting inside me.
They are standard
Standard issue, yes, I know. But where I grew up, these things would have had the conspiracy nuts all a-flutter. George Orwell, Big Brother is watching you, and all that.
Yeah, well, so, how’d you sleep?
Great.
Bad dreams again?
More like bad memories.
Sorry.
Believe me, it’s nothing to do with you.
Ah. Am I one of the good memories, then?
Not if you had anything to do with this coffee.
Door opens.
Hey, you two. I’ve been wondering when you’d show up.
Door closes.
Good morning, Sonali.
Morning.
The Professor’s been asking for you.
Me?
Yes.
Should I be jealous?
Oh, please. He’s very sweet, but he is old enough to be my father. And anyway, Geoff, I was always
under the impression that one had to actually be in a relationship to be jealous of another.
It doesn’t hurt to hope.
Melanie, could you come here, please?
Oops. Hold my coffee, will you, Geoff? Coming, Professor.
When are you going to give it a rest, Geoff?
When she flat-out tells me no. No beating around the, well, bush. Just a nice, clean, clear-cut no.
Huh. I'll believe that when I see it. (leaves)
I just hope it'll take a little longer for Mel to say it than it did for you.
Good morning, Professor.
Melanie, you do realise you kept us all waiting.
I’m really sorry. It’s just that I was trying
No. No need to worry, my dear. All that matters is that you are here now, yes?
And I’m definitely raring to go, Professor.

Excellent, excellent. Everyone gather round, please. Now, all your wonderful hard work is about to pay off. When our miners unearth the remains of the machines you see before you, most people perceive them as nothing more than potential museum pieces. Fortunately I had the vision to think otherwise. I sensed their potential, through significant modification and upgrade, of course, and the Outreach Corporation agreed with me. Now soon some of their key executives will arrive to witness a demonstration of their, of our achievement. The most advanced service robot ever created. A versatile machine that will revolutionise the mining process and augment the lives of billions of outer world colonists. You have done a truly remarkable job. And I promise you will all be suitably rewarded, once the production lines start rolling.
Thank you, Professor.
Anyway, from the bottom of my artificial heart, thank you all. Now, please return to your work. We still have much to do, and not very much time.
Hello? Who's there?
Door opens.
I don’t suppose you brought my coat? It’s just that it’s rather chilly in here, you know.
Activate lighting grid.

Oh! Oh! Bright. (beeps) Yes, that’s much better. Oh, of course. I should have guessed it was you. I think I prefer the anonymity provided by the darkness. I can’t say I’m at all pleased to see you lot. Surprise party, is it?
Silence.

And a Black Dalek as well, I see. You’ve obviously turned up for something frightfully important. Forgive me for not waving. It seems my wrists are bound. And my elbows. And my neck, for that matter. And
2: You will be silent.

You should know me better than that. Besides, the point of interrogation is to extract information from your captive. I can’t very well spill the proverbial beans if my mouth is shut, now can I? So what is it that you wish to know?
This is not an interrogation, Doctor.

Not an interrogation, eh? Well, I did notice a slight whiff of taratron in the air. Am I right in assuming that I’m standing in a molecular disintegration cage? So why am I still alive, if you don’t mind my asking?
You were ensnared within a Dalek time-scoop.
Time scoop, eh? I’m almost impressed. And my Tardis?
Your Time-Space capsule was saved from destruction.

Pardon me for not thanking you, but I was mere moments from dematerialisation, you know. Getting plucked out of Time and Space by a load of Daleks is hardly my style. I didn’t require, nor did I request your... help, is it?
You were not rescued, Doctor. You have been recruited.
I’m sorry. I didn’t Know I actually cared. Recruited for what, exactly?
To prevent the creation of a future threat to the Daleks.
Do you mean to say you’re asking me to help you? I never suspected Daleks had a sense of humour. Know any good knock knock jokes?
We require your assistance, Time Lord.
And this is where I ask, why me, exactly, hmm? Couldn’t one of your oh-so-efficient Dalek task forces sort this mess out?
The atmosphere in which this work is taking place contains a potentially lethal toxin. It is harmless to humanoid life, but it has the potential to
Exterminate the lot of you.
Correct.
How’s it going?
Oh, all right. I’m having some trouble reconfiguring the multi-task routines, but I’m almost there.
And how about in terms a lowly servo-mechanic might understand?
It won't go.
Gotcha.
You have to remember, Geoff, that up until a few months ago, the only computer languages I was adept in were Basic, COBOL, and FORTRAN.
And you used to work out your sums with an abacus, right?
Very funny.
Well, the Prof is certainly pleased with your work, and I don’t think we’d be where we are now without you.
Thanks. I appreciate that.
I think we’re almost ready, Mel.
All right, Sonali. Just let me upload my revisions. It'll only take a second.
Everything all right, Melanie?
Yes. All finished, Professor. It should be good to go.
Good. The moment of truth. Sonali, if you’d be so kind as to switch it on.
One. Input. Hundred. One. Enter.
Do you understand me?
English. Enter. Stop.
I'll assume that’s a yes.
General chuckles.
Turn left ninety degrees. Extend right grapple arm.
Enter. System. Input.
Response time, Miss Bush?
Er, point two two four.
Much better than last time, eh? Reset, and then interface with the laboratory computer.
One. Enter. One. One. Input.
Look, it’s done it.
Input. One. Enter.
Melanie, proceed with the input of the variable commands database.
Uploading now. Upload complete.
And Sonali, would you be so kind as to issue a command, please.
Oh. Of course. Command change.
One. English. Enter. Enter.
Disengage from computer then er, hoover this floor?
Enter. One. Engage.
Vacuuming sound. Laughter.
Excellent. Most excellent.
Now all we need to do is fashion an apron large enough to fasten round its thick waist.
Reset.
Reset. One. Reset.
A successful demonstration, wouldn’t you all agree?
Attention all colony personnel. Inbound shuttle Atalanta now entering solar system. Estimated time of arrival, 1800 hours.
Well, you all heard the announcement. Let’s get this place in shape for our imminent arrivals.
Hey, Professor, can’t the robot tidy up while we slip off to the canteen for a few hours?
Not this time, Mister Gatlin. Not this time. Oh, Melanie, may I see you for a moment?
Well, I really need to make a few slight alterations
The alterations can wait. Please, walk with me.
Door opens and closes.
I’m sorry my chair doesn’t move very quickly.
That’s not something you need to apologise for, Professor.
Sometimes it’s difficult to believe that once I was able to stand and walk on my own two legs. Can you imagine that, Miss Bush?
Of course, sir.

Oh, let us dispense with such formalities for the moment, Melanie. Mel. As you know, I sustained terrible injuries in the crash. The colony surgeons weren't certain they could even revive me, but they did a masterful job. Of course, when I awoke wrapped in bandages and sporting this wretched mechanical limb, my first thoughts were not of my own situation. You see, I had heard their whispers over those weeks of reconstruction. I was conscious from the moment the first laser scalpels seared my damaged tissues. I learned the impact of my shuttle had caused the deaths of dozens of colony personnel in sector six, which as you know remains damaged beyond repair. I questioned the very workings of the universe, and wondered
why so many had died while I survived.
Well, I don’t really subscribe to the concept of fate, but maybe you were meant for greater things, Professor.
Oh, perhaps, perhaps. I think the same could be said about you, Mel. You have proven to be a most valuable asset to this team. I am most impressed.
Thank you.
I would very much like you to join us in a more permanent capacity. You’d have a long and prosperous future working alongside me, Mel.
I would truly love to say yes. These past few months have been wonderful. But I just know that the Doctor will be coming for me soon, and when he arrives, I will have to say goodbye.
The Doctor. Yes. Now, he sounds like an interesting man. A good friend, hmm?
Oh definitely. He’s shown me the universe. Literally.
Well, the offer still stands. Should this Doctor fail to ever turn up, you are welcome to join us.
Thank you, Professor. I'll keep it in mind.
Beeps.
[OC]: Professor.
Excuse me, Mel. What is it, Mister Gatlin?
[OC]: The ghosts are moving again, Professor.
Are they indeed? Well, we can’t very well have that while our guests are here. Best send someone down there to give the system a once-over.
[OC]: Roger that. Oh, and hi, Mel.
Hello, Geoff.
Thank you, Mister Gatlin.
[OC]: Sorry, Prof. Bye, Mel.
What exactly did he mean by ghost?
Mister Gatlin’s rather romantic way of describing faults in the motion sensors. Every once in a while the system flutters down around the crash zone. Shall we return to the lab?
Oh, absolutely.
Silence! Silence! Silence!

No need to get your eyestalks in a tizzy. I just want to know why you actually think I would willingly volunteer to help put a stop to something that could potentially destroy you. I took you all off my Christmas list a long time ago, you know.
You are our prisoner. You have no choice but to obey the Daleks.
So you keep saying. However
We also possess your Time-Space capsule.
Yes.
You are powerless before the Daleks.
I will grant you that.
We also know of your weakness for your companions.
Go on.
We know that you wish to be reunited with the human female known as Melanie Bush.
Melanie, you say? Can’t say as I know a Melanie. I Knew a Melvin once. Discovered the muon neutrino, you know. Remarkable fellow.
You are lying
What’s the latest?
Those damn sensors in the northwest wing.
Again? I thought you took care of those last week.
I did. Checked them myself. Everything was fine. Better than fine, even.
Have you checked visual records, just in case?
Not yet. Can you bring them up?
All right, let’s see. When did the alarm first sound?
Today. Er 2:28 exactly.
Okay. Let’s start with 2:27. Camera 17, 18, 19, 20. See anything?
Nothing so far. Looks pretty normal. Wait.
I think I see it too.
There’s a shadow. Camera 19, right there. Tough to make out.
Maintenance? Bailey, perhaps. I know he was working on something down there recently.
Bailey was in the cargo bay. He spent most of last night moaning about having to work in there today.
I’m checking his log. Yeah, you’re right. He’s still there, in fact.
You know, Sonali, I hate to say this, only because it sounds completely mad, but whatever we’re
looking at, it doesn’t look human to me.
Could it be some mining equipment? They do have delta-bots in the mines, you know.
Why would a delta be wandering around the northwest wing? Plus they’re tethered, aren’t they?
Good point.
Loewen, this is Gatlin. I need you to drop what you’re doing and pop down to the northwest wing to have a look at the sensors again.
[OC]: Copy that.
Oh, and do me a favour. Be careful down there, all right?
[OC]: Right. I'll steer clear of the phantoms. Woo.
Take your staser with you, just in case.
[OC]: Seriously? Okay. Copy that, Geoff. Out.
Observe the visualiser, Doctor.
Terrible reception. Have you considered ordering a premium package? You get all the channels and
2: Image is now appearing on visualiser.
[OC]: So then the Doctor comes running out of the tomb, covered head to toe in this blue powder, shouting at me to get down. Not the first time I’ve had to dive for cover, mind you.
Ah, Mel. You’re safe.
We have you. We have your Tardis. We have your companion. You will agree to help us.
If you can assure Mel’s safety, I will agree
[OC]: Yours is a most exciting lifestyle, my dear.
No. No, surely it can’t be.
[OC]: As you have observed, my waking moments are dominated by mechanical upgrade and modification, or schematic and system [??]. I rarely if ever have time for adventure.
[OC]: Believe me, Professor, working alongside you has been a welcome break.
Davros! Surely that’s Davros!
Correct.
[OC]: Return to those adjustments, Melanie. We don’t have much time left.
[OC]: Of course. Time waits for no-one, eh, Professor?
Oh, Melanie. What has Davros done to you?

GEOFF: Mel, wait up.
MEL: Oh, good morning, Geoff.
GEOFF: I got you some coffee.

GEOFF: Ah. Am I one of the good memories, then?
MEL: Not if you had anything to do with this coffee.
SONALI: Hey, you two. I’ve been wondering when you’d show up.
MEL: Good morning, Sonali.
GEOFF: Morning.
SONALI: The Professor’s been asking for you.
MEL: Me?
SONALI: Yes.
GEOFF: Should I be jealous?
MEL: Oh, please. He’s very sweet, but he is old enough to be my father. And anyway, Geoff, I was always
MEL: under the impression that one had to actually be in a relationship to be jealous of another.
GEOFF: It doesn’t hurt to hope.
VASO: Melanie, could you come here, please?
MEL: Oops. Hold my coffee, will you, Geoff? Coming, Professor.
SONALI: When are you going to give it a rest, Geoff?
GEOFF: When she flat-out tells me no. No beating around the, well, bush. Just a nice, clean, clear-cut no.
SONALI: Huh. I'll believe that when I see it. (leaves)
GEOFF: I just hope it'll take a little longer for Mel to say it than it did for you.
MEL: Good morning, Professor.
VASO: Melanie, you do realise you kept us all waiting.
MEL: I’m really sorry. It’s just that I was trying
VASO: No. No need to worry, my dear. All that matters is that you are here now, yes?
MEL: And I’m definitely raring to go, Professor.
VASO: Excellent, excellent. Everyone gather round, please. Now, all your wonderful hard work is about to pay off. When our miners unearth the remains of the machines you see before you, most people perceive them as nothing more than potential museum pieces. Fortunately I had the vision to think otherwise. I sensed their potential, through significant modification and upgrade, of course, and the Outreach Corporation agreed with me. And I promise you will all be suitably rewarded, once the production lines start rolling.
ALL: Thank you, Professor.
VASO: Anyway, from the bottom of my artificial heart, thank you all. Now, please return to your work. We still have much to do, and not very much time.
DOCTOR: Hello? Who's there?
DOCTOR: I don’t suppose you brought my coat? It’s just that it’s rather chilly in here, you know.
BLACK DALEK: Activate lighting grid.
DOCTOR: Oh! Oh! Bright. (beeps) Yes, that’s much better. Oh, of course. I should have guessed it was you. I think I prefer the anonymity provided by the darkness. I can’t say I’m at all pleased to see you lot. Surprise party, is it?
BLACK DALEK: Silence.
DOCTOR: And a Black Dalek as well, I see. You’ve obviously turned up for something frightfully important. Forgive me for not waving. It seems my wrists are bound. And my elbows. And my neck, for that matter. And
DALEK: 2: You will be silent.
DOCTOR: You should know me better than that. Besides, the point of interrogation is to extract information from your captive. I can’t very well spill the proverbial beans if my mouth is shut, now can I? So what is it that you wish to know?

DOCTOR: Time scoop, eh? I’m almost impressed. And my Tardis?

DOCTOR: Pardon me for not thanking you, but I was mere moments from dematerialisation, you know. Getting plucked out of Time and Space by a load of Daleks is hardly my style. I didn’t require, nor did I request your... help, is it?
BLACK DALEK: You were not rescued, Doctor. You have been recruited.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry. I didn’t Know I actually cared. Recruited for what, exactly?
BLACK DALEK: To prevent the creation of a future threat to the Daleks.

MECHONOID: Enter. One. Engage.
VASO: Excellent. Most excellent.
GEOFF: Now all we need to do is fashion an apron large enough to fasten round its thick waist.
VASO: Reset.
MECHONOID: Reset. One. Reset.
VASO: A successful demonstration, wouldn’t you all agree?
TANNOY: Attention all colony personnel. Inbound shuttle Atalanta now entering solar system. Estimated time of arrival, 1800 hours.
VASO: Well, you all heard the announcement. Let’s get this place in shape for our imminent arrivals.
GEOFF: Hey, Professor, can’t the robot tidy up while we slip off to the canteen for a few hours?
VASO: Not this time, Mister Gatlin. Not this time. Oh, Melanie, may I see you for a moment?
MEL: Well, I really need to make a few slight alterations
VASO: The alterations can wait. Please, walk with me.
VASO: I’m sorry my chair doesn’t move very quickly.
MEL: That’s not something you need to apologise for, Professor.
VASO: Sometimes it’s difficult to believe that once I was able to stand and walk on my own two legs. Can you imagine that, Miss Bush?
MEL: Of course, sir.
VASO: Oh, let us dispense with such formalities for the moment, Melanie. Mel. As you know, I sustained terrible injuries in the crash. The colony surgeons weren't certain they could even revive me, but they did a masterful job. Of course, when I awoke wrapped in bandages and sporting this wretched mechanical limb, my first thoughts were not of my own situation. You see, I had heard their whispers over those weeks of reconstruction. I was conscious from the moment the first laser scalpels seared my damaged tissues. I learned the impact of my shuttle had caused the deaths of dozens of colony personnel in sector six, which as you know remains damaged beyond repair. I questioned the very workings of the universe, and wondered
VASO: why so many had died while I survived.
MEL: Well, I don’t really subscribe to the concept of fate, but maybe you were meant for greater things, Professor.
VASO: Oh, perhaps, perhaps. I think the same could be said about you, Mel. You have proven to be a most valuable asset to this team. I am most impressed.
MEL: Thank you.
VASO: I would very much like you to join us in a more permanent capacity. You’d have a long and prosperous future working alongside me, Mel.
MEL: I would truly love to say yes. These past few months have been wonderful. But I just know that the Doctor will be coming for me soon, and when he arrives, I will have to say goodbye.
VASO: The Doctor. Yes. Now, he sounds like an interesting man. A good friend, hmm?
MEL: Oh definitely. He’s shown me the universe. Literally.
VASO: Well, the offer still stands. Should this Doctor fail to ever turn up, you are welcome to join us.
MEL: Thank you, Professor. I'll keep it in mind.
GEOFF: [OC]: Professor.
VASO: Excuse me, Mel. What is it, Mister Gatlin?
GEOFF: [OC]: The ghosts are moving again, Professor.
VASO: Are they indeed? Well, we can’t very well have that while our guests are here. Best send someone down there to give the system a once-over.
GEOFF: [OC]: Roger that. Oh, and hi, Mel.
MEL: Hello, Geoff.
VASO: Thank you, Mister Gatlin.
GEOFF: [OC]: Sorry, Prof. Bye, Mel.
MEL: What exactly did he mean by ghost?
VASO: Mister Gatlin’s rather romantic way of describing faults in the motion sensors. Every once in a while the system flutters down around the crash zone. Shall we return to the lab?
MEL: Oh, absolutely.
BLACK DALEK: Silence! Silence! Silence!
DOCTOR: No need to get your eyestalks in a tizzy. I just want to know why you actually think I would willingly volunteer to help put a stop to something that could potentially destroy you. I took you all off my Christmas list a long time ago, you know.
BLACK DALEK: You are our prisoner. You have no choice but to obey the Daleks.
DOCTOR: So you keep saying. However
BLACK DALEK: We also possess your Time-Space capsule.
DOCTOR: Yes.
BLACK DALEK: You are powerless before the Daleks.
DOCTOR: I will grant you that.
BLACK DALEK: We also know of your weakness for your companions.
DOCTOR: Go on.
BLACK DALEK: We know that you wish to be reunited with the human female known as Melanie Bush.
DOCTOR: Melanie, you say? Can’t say as I know a Melanie. I Knew a Melvin once. Discovered the muon neutrino, you know. Remarkable fellow.
BLACK DALEK: You are lying
SONALI: What’s the latest?
GEOFF: Those damn sensors in the northwest wing.
SONALI: Again? I thought you took care of those last week.
GEOFF: I did. Checked them myself. Everything was fine. Better than fine, even.
SONALI: Have you checked visual records, just in case?
GEOFF: Not yet. Can you bring them up?
SONALI: All right, let’s see. When did the alarm first sound?
GEOFF: Today. Er 2:28 exactly.
SONALI: Okay. Let’s start with 2:27. Camera 17, 18, 19, 20. See anything?
GEOFF: Nothing so far. Looks pretty normal. Wait.
SONALI: I think I see it too.
GEOFF: There’s a shadow. Camera 19, right there. Tough to make out.
SONALI: Maintenance? Bailey, perhaps. I know he was working on something down there recently.
GEOFF: Bailey was in the cargo bay. He spent most of last night moaning about having to work in there today.
SONALI: I’m checking his log. Yeah, you’re right. He’s still there, in fact.
GEOFF: You know, Sonali, I hate to say this, only because it sounds completely mad, but whatever we’re
GEOFF: looking at, it doesn’t look human to me.
SONALI: Could it be some mining equipment? They do have delta-bots in the mines, you know.
GEOFF: Why would a delta be wandering around the northwest wing? Plus they’re tethered, aren’t they?
SONALI: Good point.
GEOFF: Loewen, this is Gatlin. I need you to drop what you’re doing and pop down to the northwest wing to have a look at the sensors again.
LOEWEN: [OC]: Copy that.
GEOFF: Oh, and do me a favour. Be careful down there, all right?
LOEWEN: [OC]: Right. I'll steer clear of the phantoms. Woo.
GEOFF: Take your staser with you, just in case.
LOEWEN: [OC]: Seriously? Okay. Copy that, Geoff. Out.
BLACK DALEK: Observe the visualiser, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Terrible reception. Have you considered ordering a premium package? You get all the channels and
DALEK: 2: Image is now appearing on visualiser.
MEL: [OC]: So then the Doctor comes running out of the tomb, covered head to toe in this blue powder, shouting at me to get down. Not the first time I’ve had to dive for cover, mind you.
DOCTOR: Ah, Mel. You’re safe.
BLACK DALEK: We have you. We have your Tardis. We have your companion. You will agree to help us.
DOCTOR: If you can assure Mel’s safety, I will agree
VASO: [OC]: Yours is a most exciting lifestyle, my dear.
DOCTOR: No. No, surely it can’t be.
VASO: [OC]: As you have observed, my waking moments are dominated by mechanical upgrade and modification, or schematic and system [??]. I rarely if ever have time for adventure.
MEL: [OC]: Believe me, Professor, working alongside you has been a welcome break.
DOCTOR: Davros! Surely that’s Davros!
BLACK DALEK: Correct.
VASO: [OC]: Return to those adjustments, Melanie. We don’t have much time left.
MEL: [OC]: Of course. Time waits for no-one, eh, Professor?
DOCTOR: Oh, Melanie. What has Davros done to you?

elements.text: [Part Two]
Now you understand why we require your assistance, Doctor.
Explain to me how Davros managed to once again slip from your grasp. Last I knew, he was en route to Skaro to be put on trial for his wicked crimes.
The ship conveying Davros was attacked in the vicinity of Beta Orionis. Initial reports confirmed the destruction of the ship, crew, and Davros.
Well, looks to me as though he’s been found and he’s very much alive.
Dalek agents reported unusual developments on the fringe planet of Lethe. Investigations led us to discover that Davros had integrated himself into a small human mining colony.
Tell me more.
2: We know little of his activities.
Which is why you will infiltrate the colony, investigate Davros, and report back to us. We will then decide on the subsequent course of action.
And once you’re in the know about Davros’s latest bit of nastiness, will Mel and I be free to leave?
Agreed.

(sotto) And yet I don’t believe it fora moment. (normal) Know this. I do this first and foremost to ensure the safety of my travelling companion. I will agree to do whatever I can to assist you in the recapture of your creator, and the investigation of his latest sinister activities.
Release the Doctor.
Ah. Oh, that’s better. May I have my coat now, please?
Shuttle Atalanta has now arrived. A reminder. Under space security law, all colony visitors are required to have their COMPUTERs scanned and updated upon arrival. Welcome to Lethe.
Door opens.
Hey, you two. Wow! I’ve never seen the lab this tidy.
Door closes.
And you likely never will again.
Where is everyone?
On their way. The Professor sent a welcoming party to escort the investors from the shuttle bay.
Gotcha. So how are Sooty, Sweep and Soo doing?
Two of them are exhibiting some excessive vibration in their aft servo arrays, but nothing these suits'll be able to notice.
The Professor told us to seal the hatches and leave them be for now.
Door opens.
Did someone mention my name?
(Door closes. All greet him. I'll keep calling this version of Davros ‘Vaso’ to differentiate between what people perceive him to be.)

You're all nervous, aren’t you. Don’t be. The Juggernauts will do all the work. And remember, this entire operation exists based upon the data we have been transmitting for the past year. The Outreach Corporation realised the potential for this programme a long time ago. They're not as foolish as you might think.
Then why come all the way out here? We've sent them videos, schematics, everything.
It’s the Corporate mentality, Mister Gatlin. The project cannot really be green-lit until they see it up and running with their own greedy little eyes.
Heads up, everyone. They’re coming.
Door opens.
Welcome. Welcome to you all.
Professor Vaso, I presume.
In the flesh, Mister?
Door closes.
Brauer.
Ah.
Henning Brauer. I believe you have exchanged mails and notes with Mister Kryson, Mister Valmont, and Miss Ferris.
Yes, indeed. Mister Valmont, Miss Ferris. Ah, delighted to finally meet you, Mister Kryson.
Er yes, er hello, Professor.
I must say despite never having had the chance to meet you before, we’ve certainly read all your reports with great interest..
Camera shy, I admit it. Since the accident, I’ve never been comfortable with image transmitters.
Which explains why I recognise these three, correct?
Indeed. My audio-visual ambassadors, as it were. Head of Electronics, Sonali Aptar.
Hello.
Our mechanical wizard, Geoffrey Gatlin.
Nice to meet you all.
And our programming specialist, Melanie Bush.
Hi.
I trust you had a pleasant journey?
Oh, some navigational trouble during our jump from Algernon. Apart from that it was fine, although Mister Kryson here might disagree.
A touch of space-sickness.
He spent most of the trip with a bucket clamped between his knees, if you Know what I mean.
Ah, I can fashion a suitable elixir if you’re still feeling the effects of your journey, Mister Kryson.
No, thank you. I’m fine now. I took some medicine my doctor had prepared for me.
Hardly the first time Mister Kryson has felt that way.
I see. Very well.
So, these are our Juggernauts, eh?
Yes.
They're a bit bigger than I thought.
Is that a problem?
Not as such. We’re hoping to use the retro-design as a selling point. A nod to the past. Earthers have always responded well to old things.
Don’t be fooled by their appearance. The classic styling betrays an extremely sophisticated service- bot within. If you’d be so kind, Sonali.
Of course.
Ladies and gentlemen, I present the Juggernauts!
Oh, a transmat dais. Very chic. And where, pray tell, will I be transmating to?
A subterranean cavern.
Oh, that makes a change. Sounds lovely.
You have a limited time in which to investigate Davros’s activities. We will be observing your progress via nano-cams within the colony.
That explains the pictures. I was wondering how you’d managed that.
2: Step onto the dais.
Very well. Aren’t you going to wish me bon voyage? (fading) Don’t forget to write.
Wibbled away.
All is proceeding according to plan.
Applause.
I’m impressed.
I’m very glad you think so, Mister Kryson. And what about you, Mister Brauer?
Yes, I think you’ve made quite the impression on us all. Mister Valmont was practically speechless, and he is the man in charge of financing for Outreach special projects.
Ah. The man behind the money, eh?
Now, if you don’t mind, Professor, I think we could all do with a little rest.
Oh, of course. I will have one of my staff escort you all to the guest quarters. I assume the rest of your crew and assistants are around somewhere?
Probably sitting around in our ship waiting to be told what to do.
Then I shall ensure that they know where to find you. Sonali, would you do the honours?
Of course, Professor.
Thank you. Oh, that reminds me. Professor?
Yes?
If I didn’t know better, I'd swear you were running the entire show here.
Ah. The scientific division only. All mining and production operations are handled by Commander Eckhart and his team. We tend to leave one another alone, for the most part.
Right. An equitable arrangement. Well, goodnight everyone.
Door opens and closes.
And with that I think it’s off to the canteen for a little late supper. Coming, Sonali? Mel?
No, you two go ahead. I'll sort out Brauer’s people then I’m going to give the Juggernauts a once- over, just to ease my mind.
Well, don’t stay up too late, my friends. I shall see you all tomorrow.

(sigh) Oh, these tunnels must go on for miles, and I’ve yet to see a miner. Or for that matter, seven diminutive gentlemen whistling jaunty tunes whilst they labour. Hello? Is anyone there? Oh, my kingdom for a map. Eeny, meeny. Oh, let’s just skip to the moe and head this way, shall we?
Well, I think it all went rather well, don’t you agree, Mel?
Definitely. They really seemed pleased when the Professor discussed the mining test results.
Their ears really pricked up at the mention of the words increased productivity.
So if all goes according to plan, will you stay here or head home?
Sadly, Mel, Lethe is the closest thing I have to home now. I’ve been out here so long.
Don’t you miss Earth? I mean, don’t you want to breathe the air again, or feel the grass beneath your feet? That is, if you still have grass there.
Yes, we have grass, silly.
Just checking.

On the walls of my quarters there are three holographs, looped video in five minute segments of the views from my first level flat on Earth, north, west, and south. I borrowed a friend’s hyper-real camera to shoot them and honestly, if you didn’t know there was a wall behind these things, you would swear you're looking through windows.
It sounds nice.

And it was nice. It really was. For about the first four or five months. But then I found myself conscious of every little thing in those images. I knew the exact moment when the nova-red turbo-bike would leave the frame and the titanium grey six-seater would enter. They have audio too. The occasional coo of a pigeon, footsteps on wet asphalt, the hum of the vehicles. But I turned that off a couple of weeks on. Now, well, let’s just say Earth is a long, long way away.
Do you have any family back there?
A cousin. She lives in Australia now. Married with a couple of kids, I think. We lost touch a while back. And I lost my mum and dad in the Kensington disaster back in ’97.
Oh, I’m sorry, Geoff.
Old history. How’s that shake?
Like liquid chalk. Yuk.
That good, eh? You'll notice I haven’t touched mine.
Your hands are cold.
Must be the climate controls acting up again. It’s a never ending
Kiss.
Hey, what was that for?
Oh, just a kiss. Don’t make a fuss. I like you, Geoff.
I like you too, Mel.

You and I have a lot in common, you know. I haven’t seen Earth in a long time too. Before Lethe, all I knew was the interior of the Tardis. Believe me, there’s only so much military grey one can take.
Oh, I’m sure your radiant presence was enough to brighten things up.
Oh, talk about a corny pick-up line.
Really? I thought it was rather good.

Anyway, I never could understand how a man with such flamboyant taste in clothes could tolerate those drab corridors. You’d think in nine hundred years he would have spruced the place up a little bit.
Nine hundred? This Doctor friend of yours becomes more and more interesting the more I learn about him. Nine hundred years old? Really?
Mmm. Doesn't look a day over forty five to me.
Part of me really wants to meet him some day, and the other part, well, the other part hopes our paths never cross.
Why would you say that?
If the Doctor shows up in his Tardis, is it?
Mmm.
I assume that will mean goodbye for Melanie Bush.
Well, yes. Maybe. I don’t know. I’m a bit tired, Geoff.
Can I walk you back to your quarters?
Not tonight. Goodnight. I'll see you in the morning.
Oh, wait, Mel.
Yes?
I almost forgot.
What's this?
A music box. I bought it from an antique dealer on Mars.
Tinkling music.
I don’t know the tune.
It’s Ave Maria, by Schubert.
You like it?
Yes, it’s very pretty.
Then keep it.
What?
Keep it.
Geoff, I can’t accept this.

No, I want you to have it, Mel. When you’re off wandering around space with the Doctor, far, far away from this God-forsaken place, you can always open this thing up and be reminded of goofy old Geoff, stuttering Juggernauts, and flavourless protein shakes.
I really appreciate this. Thank you. Goodnight, Geoff.
Goodnight, Mel.
Maintenance, this is Loewen. Do you copy?
[OC]: Yeah, we copy you.
Gatlin sent me down here earlier to check the sensors. I’ve been over every inch of this sector. There’s nothing wrong with this equipment.
[OC]: Copy that. Well, you’re done for the night, then. Get some rest.
Oh, thanks. Goodnight.
Rumble.
Oh great. What now? That sounds like a door alignment problem. Nothing to do with... Oh God!
screams
Knocking.
Geoff?
Door opens.
And who, may I ask, is Geoff?
Doctor!
Door closes.
I must be dreaming.
Not exactly. Hallo, Mel.
Oh, Doctor. Oh, I was beginning to think I was never going to see you again.
What? Really? I did make a promise when we parted, didn’t I?
Yes, but that was three months ago.
That long, eh? I suppose that explains the change in your hairstyle.
I haven't done a thing with it, actually.
Hmm? Well, it looks very nice all the same.
Have a seat. Sorry about the state of the place. It’s been quite a day.
Has it now? Been keeping yourself busy then?
Yes, actually. I was brought onto the scientific staff here a couple of weeks after I arrived. I must have done something to impress them, huh?
It didn’t take much effort on your part to have that effect on me.
Thanks. I think. Anyway, it’s wonderful to see you, Doctor. When did you arrive? Where’s the Tardis?
Ah. Well, that’s where things get a bit complicated.

When will this skulking about in shadows end. (beep) That was a rhetorical question. Ah, this female will be missed. We must act quickly. Activate the laser scalpel, level six. Increase to level eight.
So, after finding my way out of the mining tunnels, I accessed a terminal, located your quarters, and here I am.
So who is this Davros then?
He’s the man you’ve been working for, Mel. The man in the wheelchair.
And he created the creatures that were holding you prisoner?
Yes, I’m afraid so.
I don't believe it.
If you knew him like I know him, you’d know that he’s capable of absolute evil.
You’re mistaken, Doctor. Professor Vaso is no more capable of creating these things than, than I am. This time you are wrong.
Tell me, Mel. What does this Professor Vaso look like?
Handsome, a pleasant smile. The crash committed him to that wheelchair, but he’s as nice a man as you are ever likely to meet.
If you perceive Vaso in such a flattering light, it’s obvious he’s done something to your sensory apparatus.
You're telling me that the entire colony, everyone I know here, has been brainwashed?
Perhaps. I’m not sure yet.
That’s a bit too much for me to digest right now, Doctor.
Yes. Same here, Mel. Look, why don’t you get some rest while I do a little poking around.
Door opens.
Goodnight, Mel.
Goodnight, Doctor. Doctor?
Hmm?
It is good to see you again.
And you, Mel. And you.
Door closes.
Lights to zero.
Harmonica playing interrupted by comms.
Yes?
[OC]: Sorry to disturb you, Geoff.
No problem. I can’t sleep anyway. What’s up?
[OC]: Well, er, we’ve er lost Loewen.
What do you mean, you’ve lost her? How can you lose someone in the colony? Track her COMPUTER.
[OC]: That’s the problem. It’s been deactivated.
What could do that?
[OC]: We’re not really sure.
I assume you’ve checked her quarters.
[OC]: First thing.
When did her COMPUTER fail?
[OC]: Approximately 2200 hours, a few seconds after her last check-in.
And let me guess. Visual records don’t show anything unusual.
[OC]: No, nothing.
Oh, that’s just great. Do you need me to come up there?
[OC]: Er, no. Stay put. I just wanted to let you know. We’ve got a team scouring the area she was last detected in. I’m sure we'll find her.
Best check some of the open mining shafts. Could be she’s fallen, and the impact, I don’t know, disabled her COMPUTER or something.
[OC]: Copy that.
All right, I’ll check back with you in a few hours. I really should shut my eyes for a bit.
[OC]: All right. Goodnight, Geoff.
Lights to two.
More harmonica blues.
Mining shift D please report for duty in shaft 17.
Mmn,, this looks promising.
Warning. This is a restricted section.
Restricted, eh? Why is it restricted?
This section has been rendered condemned since it sustained irreparable damage from transport impact 716 days 5 hours 12 minutes
Thank you, thank you, you’ve made your point. And prior to this crash you know so much about, what sort of facilities would one have found beyond this door?
Storage. Surgery. Emergency environmental systems. Repair and maintenance
All relocated since the crash, yes?
Affirmative.
Thank you, disembodied computer voice. I appreciate
Door opens.
Uh oh.
And I will return once the conditioning process is complete. You will remain here until then.
Door closes.
Now I wonder what you’re up to? And with whom you were talking.
Any idea where the Professor is, Miss Bush?
No, sorry, Mister Kryson.
But I’m sure he’s on his way.
Only we don’t want to keep Mister Brauer waiting, you see. He’s a very busy man.
Oh, step back a bit, will you, Kryson. We're in the Professor’s territory now. I may be a busy man, but I’m also on occasion a patient man as well.
Sorry, Mister Brauer.
Oh, and good morning, Miss Bush, Mister Gatlin.
Door opens and closes.
A thousand apologies, everyone. I was attending to a few things elsewhere.
No worries, Professor. Give us all a chance to get a good look at these Juggernauts.
And?

Well, we're still suitably impressed. I communicated with my superiors last night and told them all about your fine presentation. They seem to agree that the Juggernauts could revolutionise mining operations on some of the key planets, particularly those bordering the tentative galactic boundaries where the deployment of organics is often a risky venture.
Precisely. They are visionaries, these superiors of yours.

They simply know a good product when they see it. They do wish to know more about the potential terraforming capabilities of these things. Could we toss a few onto proto-terrestrial planetoids and leave them to environmental conversion, for example.
This is not beyond the capabilities of the Juggernauts, yes.
Another impressive selling point, I think.
Agreed, Mister Kryson. However.
Yes?
How should I say this. They are not ready to put pen to contract just yet.
Another delay?
They would like to send in one of their own product development teams.
That is unacceptable. My staff is more than capable.
That’s as may be, but your staff is composed of colony personnel. Outreach would like to use their hand-picked experts, you see.

Mister Brauer, surely my team has proven their competence. Most of them have been involved with this project since the Juggernaut’s remains were first unearthed. Nobody knows these machines better than we do.

I know that. But considering the sheer magnitude of Outreach’s potential investment, I can understand their concern. I should hope you would be able to see things from their perspective as well, Professor.
And what exactly does this mean for us?
Mister Kryson.
Outreach would like your team to temporarily suspend any further development of the Juggernaut project.
You can’t be serious.
We are very serious. Go on, Mister Kryson.
If you do not agree to the suspension, all materials pertaining to the Juggernaut project will be removed from Lethe and transported back to Earth forthwith.
Give me a break.
Mister Gatlin, please.
All contracts with Lethean colony personnel will be null and void. However, compensation will be applied in the form of one-time individually negotiated buy-out payments.
How very kind of you.
Nothing personal.
And when will this order go into effect?
Immediately.

I’m sorry, Professor. Look on the bright side. Outreach is asking you all to step away from this project for a short while. Knowing how much effort you’ve put into this programme, I would think that you would all welcome a break.
This programme is more than just a banal day to day job, Mister Brauer. The Juggernauts are lubricated with our own blood and sweat.
We're talking about a temporary suspension.
How long?
Two, maybe three, months.
We'll give you until tomorrow morning to decide what you wish to do. I should hope that by then this laboratory will be silent and dark. (leaves.)
Professor? Professor, are you all right?
Please excuse me.
Er, what do you want us to do?
Er, return to your quarters. Go for a long walk in hydroponics. Drain the canteen of its alcohol supply. I leave it up to you. (leaves.)
Well then. First round is on me.
Coordinates G6. Magnification level 15.
Observation deck seven.
Ah, Mister Kryson. I’m pleased that you’ve agreed to meet with me.
What is this about, Professor?
Does Mister Brauer know where you are?
No. He requested some personal quiet time.
Tell me what you see.
It looks like an impact crater. A meteor strike, perhaps?
Look again. Magnification level 20.
Ah. Yes. That debris looks man-made. Wait, is that the crash site?
Indeed. A permanent scar on the surface of Lethe created when my transport slammed into both the ground and an occupied section of the colony.
Interesting. Well, thank you for showing me that, Professor, but
You know, don’t you, Kryson.
Excuse me?
I sensed it the moment you set eyes on me. You know who I am.
Yes. You can’t access the news channels without seeing wanted notices for the infamous Davros, yet somehow no-one else here seems to notice. How’ve you done it? And why hasn’t it affected me?

Simple, Kryson. You have not succumbed to my influence because you are an addict. I guessed as much from your space sickness routine. Too well rehearsed. Your bloodstream must be thick with stimulants. Oxypoxygen, penathlium perhaps. Shall I run a bioscan?
So, it’s chemical.
Viral. Engineered at molecular level.
I could have you arrested for this, you know.
And I could make your life a living hell! I have the power to release agents into the air that would feed solely on your chemically scarred brain tissues. Would you like that, Mister Kryson?
What do you want, money? I can have 50 million transferred
You insult me! You know precisely what I want.
I am a small cog in a very, very large wheel, Davros. You can’t expect me to work miracles.
Speak with your superiors back on Earth. Explain to them that their intervention is unnecessary. Convince them to authorise the mass-production of the Juggernauts immediately!
And what about Brauer?
My associates will deal with Mister Brauer. Units one, two, three, make your way to
Observation deck seven.
That was quick.
Now that’s what I call a view.
Doctor!
In the flesh.
What are you doing here?

Oh, you know me. I was in the era, and I suddenly remembered that I’ve never actually been to Lethe. Not all that impressed by what I’ve seen so far, although those distant peaks are magnificent. Oh, how do you do, Mister?
Kryson.
Charmed. Well, well, well. My, how you’ve changed.
Time does not always heal wounds, Doctor.
I take it that the new base was salvaged from one of your Necros Daleks? Oh, sorry. What a giveaway. You do know that
That Professor Vaso is really Davros? Yes, I know.
Oh, good. That saves me having to deal with long, boring explanations. And what about that hand there?
Rather impressive for human technology, don’t you think?
There really isn’t very much left of you, is there.
Wrong, Doctor. My mind is still my own.
But for how long? Fate has cast its dice for you, and the dots are in the shape of little Daleks.
No! I am not a Dalek.
You can believe whatever you like, but you grow more and more like your creations with each passing day.
I admit nature had little to do with my evolution. I point the finger of blame at you for that.

Me? What have I done? I wasn’t on Skaro when you were first toying with the Dalek idea. And I certainly wasn’t there when you fell victim to the accident that left you crippled. You’re simply unwilling to accept responsibility for your own horrific degeneration. Which conveniently leads us to the here and now. The badge on your tunic reads Vaso. Why the new moniker? Has your status as a fugitive forced you to shave off the name of Davros out of fear?

It was never my intention to become the stuff of nightmares, Doctor. The Daleks were meant to bring order to the swirling chaos of the universe. I am, or rather, I was, Davros. It was my dream, and perhaps, I admit, a foolish one, to have my name live on long after me. I desired a legacy.
But the Daleks wouldn’t allow that, would they? Something about being all-powerful and superior? There was no place for you in their masterplan, was there?

I created them, and they tried to destroy me. And ever since, I have been cursed. They come to me out of necessity, out of desperation, expecting me to solve their problems for them. I have had enough!
And so you went into hiding.

The attack on and resultant destruction of the Dalek transport was fortuitous. My initial scars were enough to hide my true identity, and so I took advantage of the situation, and Vaso was born. Arriving here on this planet has afforded me a chance to start anew, a chance to shed Davros like a malavolte sheds its summer coat. They like me here, Doctor.

They like what they perceive you to be, Davros. Your genetic tampering has already started things off on the wrong foot. Once your colleagues learn the truth they will hate you, and the cycle will begin all over again. So predictable, Davros. So like you.
It is of no matter, Doctor. My work here is paramount.
And just what is it that you are doing here on Lethe, Davros. Sorry, I mean Professor Vaso.
You summoned us, Davros.
Good God. Daleks? Of course, I should have known.

BLACK DALEK: Now you understand why we require your assistance, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Explain to me how Davros managed to once again slip from your grasp. Last I knew, he was en route to Skaro to be put on trial for his wicked crimes.
BLACK DALEK: The ship conveying Davros was attacked in the vicinity of Beta Orionis. Initial reports confirmed the destruction of the ship, crew, and Davros.
DOCTOR: Well, looks to me as though he’s been found and he’s very much alive.
BLACK DALEK: Dalek agents reported unusual developments on the fringe planet of Lethe. Investigations led us to discover that Davros had integrated himself into a small human mining colony.
DOCTOR: Tell me more.
DALEK: 2: We know little of his activities.
BLACK DALEK: Which is why you will infiltrate the colony, investigate Davros, and report back to us. We will then decide on the subsequent course of action.
DOCTOR: And once you’re in the know about Davros’s latest bit of nastiness, will Mel and I be free to leave?
BLACK DALEK: Agreed.
DOCTOR: (sotto) And yet I don’t believe it fora moment. (normal) Know this. I do this first and foremost to ensure the safety of my travelling companion. I will agree to do whatever I can to assist you in the recapture of your creator, and the investigation of his latest sinister activities.
BLACK DALEK: Release the Doctor.
DOCTOR: Ah. Oh, that’s better. May I have my coat now, please?
TANNOY: Shuttle Atalanta has now arrived. A reminder. Under space security law, all colony visitors are required to have their COMPUTERs scanned and updated upon arrival. Welcome to Lethe.
MEL: Hey, you two. Wow! I’ve never seen the lab this tidy.
GEOFF: And you likely never will again.
MEL: Where is everyone?
SONALI: On their way. The Professor sent a welcoming party to escort the investors from the shuttle bay.
MEL: Gotcha. So how are Sooty, Sweep and Soo doing?
GEOFF: Two of them are exhibiting some excessive vibration in their aft servo arrays, but nothing these suits'll be able to notice.
SONALI: The Professor told us to seal the hatches and leave them be for now.
VASO: Did someone mention my name?
VASO: (Door closes. All greet him. I'll keep calling this version of Davros ‘Vaso’ to differentiate between what people perceive him to be.)
VASO: You're all nervous, aren’t you. Don’t be. The Juggernauts will do all the work. And remember, this entire operation exists based upon the data we have been transmitting for the past year. The Outreach Corporation realised the potential for this programme a long time ago. They're not as foolish as you might think.
GEOFF: Then why come all the way out here? We've sent them videos, schematics, everything.
VASO: It’s the Corporate mentality, Mister Gatlin. The project cannot really be green-lit until they see it up and running with their own greedy little eyes.
SONALI: Heads up, everyone. They’re coming.
VASO: Welcome. Welcome to you all.
BRAUER: Professor Vaso, I presume.
VASO: In the flesh, Mister?
BRAUER: Brauer.
VASO: Ah.
BRAUER: Henning Brauer. I believe you have exchanged mails and notes with Mister Kryson, Mister Valmont, and Miss Ferris.
VASO: Yes, indeed. Mister Valmont, Miss Ferris. Ah, delighted to finally meet you, Mister Kryson.
KRYSON: Er yes, er hello, Professor.
BRAUER: I must say despite never having had the chance to meet you before, we’ve certainly read all your reports with great interest..
VASO: Camera shy, I admit it. Since the accident, I’ve never been comfortable with image transmitters.
BRAUER: Which explains why I recognise these three, correct?
VASO: Indeed. My audio-visual ambassadors, as it were. Head of Electronics, Sonali Aptar.
SONALI: Hello.
VASO: Our mechanical wizard, Geoffrey Gatlin.
GEOFF: Nice to meet you all.
VASO: And our programming specialist, Melanie Bush.
MEL: Hi.
VASO: I trust you had a pleasant journey?
BRAUER: Oh, some navigational trouble during our jump from Algernon. Apart from that it was fine, although Mister Kryson here might disagree.
KRYSON: A touch of space-sickness.
BRAUER: He spent most of the trip with a bucket clamped between his knees, if you Know what I mean.
VASO: Ah, I can fashion a suitable elixir if you’re still feeling the effects of your journey, Mister Kryson.
KRYSON: No, thank you. I’m fine now. I took some medicine my doctor had prepared for me.
BRAUER: Hardly the first time Mister Kryson has felt that way.
VASO: I see. Very well.
BRAUER: So, these are our Juggernauts, eh?
VASO: Yes.
KRYSON: They're a bit bigger than I thought.
VASO: Is that a problem?
BRAUER: Not as such. We’re hoping to use the retro-design as a selling point. A nod to the past. Earthers have always responded well to old things.
VASO: Don’t be fooled by their appearance. The classic styling betrays an extremely sophisticated service- bot within. If you’d be so kind, Sonali.
SONALI: Of course.
VASO: Ladies and gentlemen, I present the Juggernauts!
DOCTOR: Oh, a transmat dais. Very chic. And where, pray tell, will I be transmating to?
BLACK DALEK: A subterranean cavern.
DOCTOR: Oh, that makes a change. Sounds lovely.
BLACK DALEK: You have a limited time in which to investigate Davros’s activities. We will be observing your progress via nano-cams within the colony.
DOCTOR: That explains the pictures. I was wondering how you’d managed that.
DALEK: 2: Step onto the dais.
DOCTOR: Very well. Aren’t you going to wish me bon voyage? (fading) Don’t forget to write.
BLACK DALEK: All is proceeding according to plan.
KRYSON: I’m impressed.
VASO: I’m very glad you think so, Mister Kryson. And what about you, Mister Brauer?
BRAUER: Yes, I think you’ve made quite the impression on us all. Mister Valmont was practically speechless, and he is the man in charge of financing for Outreach special projects.
VASO: Ah. The man behind the money, eh?
BRAUER: Now, if you don’t mind, Professor, I think we could all do with a little rest.
VASO: Oh, of course. I will have one of my staff escort you all to the guest quarters. I assume the rest of your crew and assistants are around somewhere?
KRYSON: Probably sitting around in our ship waiting to be told what to do.
VASO: Then I shall ensure that they know where to find you. Sonali, would you do the honours?
SONALI: Of course, Professor.
BRAUER: Thank you. Oh, that reminds me. Professor?
VASO: Yes?
BRAUER: If I didn’t know better, I'd swear you were running the entire show here.
VASO: Ah. The scientific division only. All mining and production operations are handled by Commander Eckhart and his team. We tend to leave one another alone, for the most part.
BRAUER: Right. An equitable arrangement. Well, goodnight everyone.
GEOFF: And with that I think it’s off to the canteen for a little late supper. Coming, Sonali? Mel?
SONALI: No, you two go ahead. I'll sort out Brauer’s people then I’m going to give the Juggernauts a once- over, just to ease my mind.
VASO: Well, don’t stay up too late, my friends. I shall see you all tomorrow.
DOCTOR: (sigh) Oh, these tunnels must go on for miles, and I’ve yet to see a miner. Or for that matter, seven diminutive gentlemen whistling jaunty tunes whilst they labour. Hello? Is anyone there? Oh, my kingdom for a map. Eeny, meeny. Oh, let’s just skip to the moe and head this way, shall we?
GEOFF: Well, I think it all went rather well, don’t you agree, Mel?
MEL: Definitely. They really seemed pleased when the Professor discussed the mining test results.
GEOFF: Their ears really pricked up at the mention of the words increased productivity.
MEL: So if all goes according to plan, will you stay here or head home?
GEOFF: Sadly, Mel, Lethe is the closest thing I have to home now. I’ve been out here so long.
MEL: Don’t you miss Earth? I mean, don’t you want to breathe the air again, or feel the grass beneath your feet? That is, if you still have grass there.
GEOFF: Yes, we have grass, silly.
MEL: Just checking.
GEOFF: On the walls of my quarters there are three holographs, looped video in five minute segments of the views from my first level flat on Earth, north, west, and south. I borrowed a friend’s hyper-real camera to shoot them and honestly, if you didn’t know there was a wall behind these things, you would swear you're looking through windows.
MEL: It sounds nice.
GEOFF: And it was nice. It really was. For about the first four or five months. But then I found myself conscious of every little thing in those images. I knew the exact moment when the nova-red turbo-bike would leave the frame and the titanium grey six-seater would enter. They have audio too. The occasional coo of a pigeon, footsteps on wet asphalt, the hum of the vehicles. But I turned that off a couple of weeks on. Now, well, let’s just say Earth is a long, long way away.
MEL: Do you have any family back there?
GEOFF: A cousin. She lives in Australia now. Married with a couple of kids, I think. We lost touch a while back. And I lost my mum and dad in the Kensington disaster back in ’97.
MEL: Oh, I’m sorry, Geoff.
GEOFF: Old history. How’s that shake?
MEL: Like liquid chalk. Yuk.
GEOFF: That good, eh? You'll notice I haven’t touched mine.
MEL: Your hands are cold.
GEOFF: Must be the climate controls acting up again. It’s a never ending
GEOFF: Hey, what was that for?
MEL: Oh, just a kiss. Don’t make a fuss. I like you, Geoff.
GEOFF: I like you too, Mel.
MEL: You and I have a lot in common, you know. I haven’t seen Earth in a long time too. Before Lethe, all I knew was the interior of the Tardis. Believe me, there’s only so much military grey one can take.
GEOFF: Oh, I’m sure your radiant presence was enough to brighten things up.
MEL: Oh, talk about a corny pick-up line.
GEOFF: Really? I thought it was rather good.
MEL: Anyway, I never could understand how a man with such flamboyant taste in clothes could tolerate those drab corridors. You’d think in nine hundred years he would have spruced the place up a little bit.
GEOFF: Nine hundred? This Doctor friend of yours becomes more and more interesting the more I learn about him. Nine hundred years old? Really?
MEL: Mmm. Doesn't look a day over forty five to me.
GEOFF: Part of me really wants to meet him some day, and the other part, well, the other part hopes our paths never cross.
MEL: Why would you say that?
GEOFF: If the Doctor shows up in his Tardis, is it?
MEL: Mmm.
GEOFF: I assume that will mean goodbye for Melanie Bush.
MEL: Well, yes. Maybe. I don’t know. I’m a bit tired, Geoff.
GEOFF: Can I walk you back to your quarters?
MEL: Not tonight. Goodnight. I'll see you in the morning.
GEOFF: Oh, wait, Mel.
MEL: Yes?
GEOFF: I almost forgot.
MEL: What's this?
GEOFF: A music box. I bought it from an antique dealer on Mars.
GEOFF: I don’t know the tune.
MEL: It’s Ave Maria, by Schubert.
GEOFF: You like it?
MEL: Yes, it’s very pretty.
GEOFF: Then keep it.
MEL: What?
GEOFF: Keep it.
MEL: Geoff, I can’t accept this.
GEOFF: No, I want you to have it, Mel. When you’re off wandering around space with the Doctor, far, far away from this God-forsaken place, you can always open this thing up and be reminded of goofy old Geoff, stuttering Juggernauts, and flavourless protein shakes.
MEL: I really appreciate this. Thank you. Goodnight, Geoff.
GEOFF: Goodnight, Mel.
LOEWEN: Maintenance, this is Loewen. Do you copy?
MAN: [OC]: Yeah, we copy you.
LOEWEN: Gatlin sent me down here earlier to check the sensors. I’ve been over every inch of this sector. There’s nothing wrong with this equipment.
MAN: [OC]: Copy that. Well, you’re done for the night, then. Get some rest.
LOEWEN: Oh, thanks. Goodnight.
LOEWEN: Oh great. What now? That sounds like a door alignment problem. Nothing to do with... Oh God!
MEL: Geoff?

MEL: Doctor!
MEL: I must be dreaming.
DOCTOR: Not exactly. Hallo, Mel.
MEL: Oh, Doctor. Oh, I was beginning to think I was never going to see you again.
DOCTOR: What? Really? I did make a promise when we parted, didn’t I?
MEL: Yes, but that was three months ago.
DOCTOR: That long, eh? I suppose that explains the change in your hairstyle.
MEL: I haven't done a thing with it, actually.

MEL: Have a seat. Sorry about the state of the place. It’s been quite a day.

MEL: Yes, actually. I was brought onto the scientific staff here a couple of weeks after I arrived. I must have done something to impress them, huh?

MEL: Thanks. I think. Anyway, it’s wonderful to see you, Doctor. When did you arrive? Where’s the Tardis?
DOCTOR: Ah. Well, that’s where things get a bit complicated.
DAVROS: When will this skulking about in shadows end. (beep) That was a rhetorical question. Ah, this female will be missed. We must act quickly. Activate the laser scalpel, level six. Increase to level eight.
DOCTOR: So, after finding my way out of the mining tunnels, I accessed a terminal, located your quarters, and here I am.

DOCTOR: He’s the man you’ve been working for, Mel. The man in the wheelchair.

MEL: That’s a bit too much for me to digest right now, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Yes. Same here, Mel. Look, why don’t you get some rest while I do a little poking around.
DOCTOR: Goodnight, Mel.
MEL: Goodnight, Doctor. Doctor?
DOCTOR: Hmm?
MEL: It is good to see you again.
DOCTOR: And you, Mel. And you.

GEOFF: Yes?
MAN: [OC]: Sorry to disturb you, Geoff.
GEOFF: No problem. I can’t sleep anyway. What’s up?

GEOFF: What do you mean, you’ve lost her? How can you lose someone in the colony? Track her COMPUTER.
MAN: [OC]: That’s the problem. It’s been deactivated.
GEOFF: What could do that?
MAN: [OC]: We’re not really sure.
GEOFF: I assume you’ve checked her quarters.
MAN: [OC]: First thing.

GEOFF: And let me guess. Visual records don’t show anything unusual.
MAN: [OC]: No, nothing.

MAN: [OC]: Er, no. Stay put. I just wanted to let you know. We’ve got a team scouring the area she was last detected in. I’m sure we'll find her.
GEOFF: Best check some of the open mining shafts. Could be she’s fallen, and the impact, I don’t know, disabled her COMPUTER or something.
MAN: [OC]: Copy that.
GEOFF: All right, I’ll check back with you in a few hours. I really should shut my eyes for a bit.
MAN: [OC]: All right. Goodnight, Geoff.
GEOFF: Lights to two.

DOCTOR: Mmn,, this looks promising.

COMPUTER: This section has been rendered condemned since it sustained irreparable damage from transport impact 716 days 5 hours 12 minutes
DOCTOR: Thank you, thank you, you’ve made your point. And prior to this crash you know so much about, what sort of facilities would one have found beyond this door?
COMPUTER: Storage. Surgery. Emergency environmental systems. Repair and maintenance
DOCTOR: All relocated since the crash, yes?
COMPUTER: Affirmative.
DOCTOR: Thank you, disembodied computer voice. I appreciate

DAVROS: And I will return once the conditioning process is complete. You will remain here until then.
DOCTOR: Now I wonder what you’re up to? And with whom you were talking.

MEL: No, sorry, Mister Kryson.

KRYSON: Only we don’t want to keep Mister Brauer waiting, you see. He’s a very busy man.
BRAUER: Oh, step back a bit, will you, Kryson. We're in the Professor’s territory now. I may be a busy man, but I’m also on occasion a patient man as well.
KRYSON: Sorry, Mister Brauer.
BRAUER: Oh, and good morning, Miss Bush, Mister Gatlin.
VASO: A thousand apologies, everyone. I was attending to a few things elsewhere.
BRAUER: No worries, Professor. Give us all a chance to get a good look at these Juggernauts.

BRAUER: Well, we're still suitably impressed. I communicated with my superiors last night and told them all about your fine presentation. VASO: Precisely. They are visionaries, these superiors of yours.
BRAUER: They simply know a good product when they see it. They do wish to know more about the potential terraforming capabilities of these things. Could we toss a few onto proto-terrestrial planetoids and leave them to environmental conversion, for example.
VASO: This is not beyond the capabilities of the Juggernauts, yes.
KRYSON: Another impressive selling point, I think.
BRAUER: Agreed, Mister Kryson. However.
VASO: Yes?

VASO: Another delay?
BRAUER: They would like to send in one of their own product development teams.
VASO: That is unacceptable. My staff is more than capable.
BRAUER: That’s as may be, but your staff is composed of colony personnel. Outreach would like to use their hand-picked experts, you see.
VASO: Mister Brauer, surely my team has proven their competence. Most of them have been involved with this project since the Juggernaut’s remains were first unearthed. Nobody knows these machines better than we do.
BRAUER: I know that. But considering the sheer magnitude of Outreach’s potential investment, I can understand their concern. I should hope you would be able to see things from their perspective as well, Professor.
VASO: And what exactly does this mean for us?
BRAUER: Mister Kryson.

VASO: Mister Gatlin, please.
KRYSON: All contracts with Lethean colony personnel will be null and void. However, compensation will be applied in the form of one-time individually negotiated buy-out payments.
MEL: How very kind of you.
BRAUER: Nothing personal.
VASO: And when will this order go into effect?
